posts.name: Falon Clark
posts.cooked: is there something wrong with my AdvantageKit config?, my logged ouputs arent showing up in sim

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
Is this your entire configuration? Are you calling Logger.start() ? You’ll also want to make sure that setUseTiming(false) is not being called, since that will prevent the code from running in real time.

You’ll also want to add an option for configuring AdvantageKit in replay mode. The example projects show one method, but there are many options to support running in all three modes: real, replay, and physics sim.

posts.name: Falon Clark
posts.cooked: Oh my god im braindead, I forgot logger.start

posts.name: Falon Clark
posts.cooked: So now I get the realOutputs table, but none of my @AutoLogOuput methods are showing up

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: Make sure that you’re using the annotation in a compatible location, see the end of this section for a list of restrictions about where @AutoLogOutput can be used:

posts.name: Falon Clark
posts.cooked: it should be fine based on that, unless it doesn’t work in kotlin objects (singletons) even if they’re called for the first time in robot container

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
See this issue:

AutoLogOutput doesn't work with Kotlin objects when they are not stored as fields opened 06:33PM - 15 Mar 24 UTC naturecodevoid

AutoLogOutput doesn't work with Kotlin objects when they are not stored as fields opened 06:33PM - 15 Mar 24 UTC naturecodevoid

opened 06:33PM - 15 Mar 24 UTC naturecodevoid

opened 06:33PM - 15 Mar 24 UTC

naturecodevoid

If you store your RobotContainer and subsystems as Kotlin objects (singletons), … AutoLogOutputManager will not pick up on them because they are not stored as fields.

Seeing as though [finding all Kotlin objects using reflection is not feasible](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42401781/how-to-find-all-classes-in-a-package-using-reflection-in-kotlin), it would be great to be able to call the `registerFields` method of AutoLogOutputManager manually to avoid storing objects as fields.

For now, we can do it via reflection:
```kotlin
fun registerFieldsForAutoLogOutput(root: Any) {
    val method = AutoLogOutputManager::class.java.getDeclaredMethod("registerFields", Object::class.java)
    method.isAccessible = true
    method.invoke(null, root)
}

// ... in robotInit ...
registerFieldsForAutoLogOutput(RobotContainer)

// ... in RobotContainer ...
registerFieldsForAutoLogOutput(Drive)
```

If you store your RobotContainer and subsystems as Kotlin objects (singletons), … AutoLogOutputManager will not pick up on them because they are not stored as fields.

Seeing as though [finding all Kotlin objects using reflection is not feasible](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42401781/how-to-find-all-classes-in-a-package-using-reflection-in-kotlin), it would be great to be able to call the `registerFields` method of AutoLogOutputManager manually to avoid storing objects as fields.

For now, we can do it via reflection:
```kotlin
fun registerFieldsForAutoLogOutput(root: Any) {
    val method = AutoLogOutputManager::class.java.getDeclaredMethod("registerFields", Object::class.java)
    method.isAccessible = true
    method.invoke(null, root)
}

// ... in robotInit ...
registerFieldsForAutoLogOutput(RobotContainer)

// ... in RobotContainer ...
registerFieldsForAutoLogOutput(Drive)
```

Kotlin support for both AutoLog and AutoLogOutput is a bit incomplete right now.

link_counts.title: AutoLogOutput doesn't work with Kotlin objects when they are not stored as fields · Issue #86 · Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit · GitHub

posts.name: Falon Clark
posts.cooked: no worries! Understandable considering it’s not officially supported, i wanted to switch to classes for my subsystems anyways for other reasons, i really appreciate your fast responses
